subject: Re: How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... a ... from ... that ... Sounds like Smalltalk. And Python, for that matter. People manage to write code in those languages without any problems. ... I ...
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Elliotte Harold <elharo@m...> wrote:
> Let me ask you this. How would you feel about making "private" just
a
> suggestion? i.e. why not allow anyone to invoke any private method
from
> any class they want to? Of course, they would know when doing this
that
> they were doing something skanky. Would you be happy with such a
> language? If not, why not?

Sounds like Smalltalk. And Python, for that matter. People manage to
write code in those languages without any problems.

> If you think the private keyword should be just a suggestion, then
I
> think we will just have to agree to disagree at this point.

The private keyword _is_ only a suggestion. It's a strong suggestion,
one that the compiler respects, but one that is not guaranteed to be
honoured by the runtime environment.

Out of curiousity: if you couldn't have private methods, would you
change your coding style at all? Would that approach end up being
better, or worse? Would you consider trying it out?

(I have, it did change my style, and I believe it was for the better -
but that's me)

> But if you
> don't think private is unnecessary, then I think there's a
contradiction
> in your philosophy that's worth exploring further.

Indeed. Now, do you think it's possible to write code without a
private keyword? If not, how do you explain, for example, Smalltalk
and Python? If you do, then I think there's a contradiction in your
philosophy that's worth exploring further.

Or should we just end the discussion?

[Quick digression: Python does have private methods of a sort... but
they _are_ a naming convention (leading double underscores), which are
only partly enforced by the environment. To quote _Dive Into Python_:
"If you try to call a private method, Python will raise a slightly
misleading exception, saying that the method does not exist. Of course
it does exist, but it's private, so it's not accessible outside the
class.Strictly speaking, private methods are accessible outside their
class, just not easily accessible. Nothing in Python is truly private;
internally, the names of private methods and attributes are mangled
and unmangled on the fly to make them seem inaccessible by their given
names. You can access the __parse method of the MP3FileInfo class by
the name _MP3FileInfo__parse. Acknowledge that this is interesting,
but promise to never, ever do it in real code. Private methods are
private for a reason, but like many other things in Python, their
privateness is ultimately a matter of convention, not force.}]
